channel.title: Intro to Java
channel.description:
Got this book on my iPod and I figured I would share to you guys. Just going to type everything out, and I found it very informative. All of the images are up now. Now just to make them match the background. :P [B][SIZE=18pt]Table of Contents[/SIZE][/b] [b][SIZE=14pt]Introduction[/SIZE][/B] 1.1 Introduction 1.2 What Is Java? [B][SIZE=14pt]Compiling and Running Java[/SIZE][/B] 2.1 Hello World 2.2 Compiling HelloWorld 2.3 Running HelloWorld 2.4 Review 2.5 Dissecting HelloWorld 2.6 Commenting Code [B][SIZE=14pt]Variables and Data Types[/SIZE][/B] 3.1 Variables 3.2 Data Types: Primitive and Reference 3.3 Integers: int, long, short and byte 3.4 Real Numbers: float and double 3.5 Character Data: char 3.6 boolean [SIZE=14pt][B]Expressions and Operators[/B][/SIZE] 4.1 Expressions Intro 4.2 Assignment Operators 4.3 Arithmetic Operators 4.4 Increment/Decrement 4.5 Equality and Relational Operators 4.6 Conditional (Boolean) Operators [SIZE=14pt][B]Strings[/B][/SIZE] 5.1 Strings 5.2 Immutability 5.3 The substring() method 5.4 Testing for Equality [B][SIZE=14pt]Program Flow[/SIZE][/B] 6.1 Control Structures 6.2 if 6.3 while 6.4 do/while 6.5 for loop 6.6 break 6.7 continue 6.8 switch [B][SIZE=14pt]Arrays[/SIZE][/B] 7.1 Arrays 7.2 Multidimensional Arrays [B][SIZE=14pt]Subroutines[/SIZE][/B] 8.1 Subroutines 8.2 Methods 8.3 Method Modifiers 8.4 Returning Data 8.5 Parameters [B][SIZE=14pt]Object Orientated Programming[/SIZE][/B] 9.1 Object Oriented Programming 9.2 Classes 9.3 null 9.4 Instance Variables 9.5 Class Variables 9.6 Accessors: getters and setters 9.7 Constructors 9.8 "this" 9.9 Class Methods (static methods) 9.10 Interfaces 9.11 Implementing Multiple Interfaces [B][SIZE=14pt]Exceptions[/SIZE][/B] 10.1 Exceptions 10.2 Throwing Exceptions 10.3 Two Major Kinds of Exceptions 10.4 Checked Exceptions 10.5 Unchecked Exceptions [SIZE=14pt][B]Advanced Object Oriented Programming[/B][/SIZE] 11.1 Inheritance 11.2 Overriding 11.3 super 11.4 Abstract Methods 11.5 Abstract Classes 11.6 Polymorphism [B][SIZE=14pt]Collections[/SIZE][/B] 12.1 Collections 12.2 List 12.3 ArrayList 12.4 LinkedList 12.5 Set 12.6 Map 12.7 HashMap 12.8 Generics [B][SIZE=14pt]Odds and Ends[/SIZE][/B] 13.1 packages 13.2 The import Statement 13.3 Wrappers for the Primitive Types 13.4 Autoboxing Primitives [B][SIZE=14pt]Advanced Topics[/SIZE][/B] 14.1 Garbage Collection & Memory Management 14.2 Reachable vs Unreachable Objects 14.3 Falling Out of Scope [SIZE=14pt][b]Introduction[/b][/SIZE] This guide is a basic introduction to programming in the Java Language. While suitable for any beginner, it is primarily intended for the Freshman-level Computer Science students, or for High School AP Computer Science class students. A basic familiarity with computers is assumed. We will cover the basics of compiling and running Java programs on the command line, but we will not cover IDEs (Integrated Development Environments) such as Exclipse or Netbeans. In general, it's best to use whatever programming environment your instructor recommends, since much can depend on the software available at your school. [SIZE=14pt][b]What is Java?[/b][/size] Java is a high-level, object-oriented programming language. Java source code is compiled into [i]byte code[/i], which then runs in a Java Virtual Machine or [i]JVM[/i]. The JVM [i]interprets[/i] the byte code. It is the JVM that allows Java code to run on almost any computer or operating system, from cellphones, to PCs, to supercomputers. Java includes an immense set of libraries and APIs, but this guide will focus only on the language basics as typically used in an introductory Computer Science programming class. [SIZE=14pt][b]Hello World[/b][/size] In programming language documentation it is traditional to start with a very simple program, the simplest way possible to print the words "Hello World!" to the screen. (Please excuse my conventions as it won't let me use the tab key for some odd reason.) [code=Java] public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } } [/code] Save this text into a file named "HelloWorld.java". [SIZE=14pt][b]Compiling HelloWorld[/b][/size] We use the "javac" command to compile our code. If you're working on the command line, you would type something like this: [code=Java]javac HelloWorld.java[/code] If all is well, it will run without printing anything, and you should end up with a HelloWorld.class file in your directory. If you get any error messages, verify that you have typed everything in correctly and saved any changes before trying to compile again. [SIZE=14pt][b]Running HelloWorld[/b][/size] Now that you've compiled our program, you can run it with the following command: [code=Java]java HelloWorld[/code] Note that the command we're using is "java", without the "c" at the end, and the argument is "HelloWorld" without the ".java" after it. When you run it, you should see the program print "Hello World!" to your screen. [SIZE=14pt][b]HelloWorld Review[/b][/size] So what have we actually accomplished here? After creating our program in a text editor, we [i]compiled[/i] it. The compiler translated out textual program into byte code, storing the results into a file called HelloWorld.class. Then we [i]ran[/i] the program in the Java Virtual Machine. The JVM read in the byte code from HelloWorld.class, [i]interpreted[/i] the instructions generated by the compiler, which resulted in the words "Hello World!" being printed to our screen. Make sure you are able to compile and run HelloWorld in your environment before continuing. [SIZE=14pt][b]Dissecting HelloWorld[/b][/size] Let's dissect HelloWorld line by line.
public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } }
public class HelloWorld declared the name of the [i]class[/i] to be HelloWorld. Later we'll discuss in more detail what a class is, but for now you can consider it to be a kind of container for your code. The class name must match the name of your .java file.
public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } }
public static void main is a special method that serves as an entry point when running your program. When the JVM starts up, it loads the class file that was specified and looks for a method named "main". Any class may declare such a method, which then allows it to be the starting point when the program runs.
public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } }
String[] args declares that the main method takes an array of String arguments. This allows you to get access to whatever arguments were specified to your program (if any) when it was launched by the user. For example, the following code will print out whatever name the user typed when the program was launched: [code=Java] public static void main(String[] args) { String username = args[0]; System.out.println("Hello " + username); }[/code]
public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } }
System.out.println is a [i]method[/i] that prints a line of text. To be more precise, System is a Java class that contains a PrintStream object named out. So this line of code simply calls the println method of out, with the String that we pass in as an argument. [SIZE=14pt][b]Commenting Code[/b][/size] Although programs are written for the computer to execute, we still need a way to make them understandable by [i]humans[/i]. Java has two ways to include [i]comments[/i] in your programs- lines of text that are ignored by the compiler, but are helpful to people reading the code. [SIZE=14pt][b]Commenting Code- //[/b][/size] The compiler will ignore any text that comes after two forward slashes- //, until the end of that line. [code=Java] // A program to print a simple // message to the screen. // public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello World!"); } } [/code] You can also include comments on the same line as program code. [code=Java] int weight; // in pounds[/code] [SIZE=14pt][b]Commenting Code- /* */[/b][/size] Another way to add comments to code is to place them between /* and */. This style of commenting allows comments to be placed anywhere, even on multiple lines. [code=Java] /* A program to print a simple message to the screen. */ public class HelloWorld { /* main entry point */ public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello world!"); } }[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Variables[/size][/b] In programming, we use the term variable to indicate a named piece of computer memory which we use to store (and manipulate) data. Before a variable can be used, it and its type must be [i]declared[/i]. [code=Java] int x; // declares an integer named "x"[/code] Once it has been declared, we can [i]assign[/i] a value to a variable with the = operator. [code=Java] int x; x = 8196;[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Primitive vs Reference Types[/size][/b] As you might expect, in Java we have different [i]types[/i] to represent different types of data. There are two main kinds of data in Java- primitive types and reference types. Reference types are things such as Objects and Arrays, which need to be created dynamically with the "new" keyword. We will cover reference types later. Primitives in Java are built-in types that are automatically allocated, and are passed by [i]value[/i], rather than reference. [b][SIZE=14pt]The Integer Types: int[/size][/b] int is a primitive type. As we saw in the previous section, an int is allocated simply by declaring it. [code=Java] int weight;[/code] In Java, an int is represented in your computer's memory with 4 bytes, or 32 bits. This means that int is big enough to hold values from -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647. int is a good default choice for representing integer numbers in Java. [b][SIZE=14pt]The Integer Types: long[/size][/b] Another integer type is long. long is composed of 8 bytes (64 bits), and is large enough to hold values ranging from -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807. Use long only when you need to store data that is out of range for int. [code=Java] long millis = System.currentTimeMillis();[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]The Integer Types: short[/size][/b] As its name implies, short is composed of only 2 bytes (16 bits), and is large enough to hold values ranging from -32,768 to 32,767. [code=Java] short numStudents = 156;[/code] Use short only when you are sure that your values will fit in the range -32,768 to 32,767. [b][SIZE=14pt]The Integer Types: byte[/size][/b] A byte in Java represents a single byte (8 bits). It can hold integer values from -128 to 127. Arrays of bytes are often used to hold low-level data, such as pixel color data for images, or audio bytes from an mp3 file. [code=Java] byte b = 10;[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Real Numbers: float[/size][/b] float is used to represent floating point (real, i.e. non-integer) numbers. float uses 4 bytes to store values up to approximately 10[sup]38[/sup], positive or negative, with about 7 significant figures. [code=Java] float PI = 3.14159;[/code] Where it would otherwise be ambiguous, you can differentiate floats from integers in your code by appending f to numbers. [code=Java] float floatingThree = 3f;[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Real Numbers: double[/size][/b] double is a double-sized float, which uses 8 bytes rather than 4, and can store values up to approximately 10[sup]308[/sup], positive or negative, with about 15 significant figures. Append a d to a number to indicate that it should be a double. [code=Java] double trouble = 99.9999d;[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Character data: char[/size][/b] The char primitive is used for character data. A char holds a single character of data, such as the letter 'A', or the number '0', or the symbol '@'. [code=Java] char c = 'x';[/code] char data is based on the Unicode specification, which allows it to represent the many characters of the world's languages. [b][SIZE=14pt]boolean[/size][/b] boolean can hold boolean data- true or false. Note also the true and false keywords. You must spell them as indicated, all lowercase or they will not be recognized by the compiler. [code=Java] boolean b1 = true; boolean b2 = false;[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Expressions and Operators[/size][/b] Expressions are statements that represent or calculate a value. The value, or [i]result[/i] of an expression can be assigned to a variable or passed in as an argument to a method. Using [i]operators[/i], expressions can be combined to produce even more complicated expressions. You have already seen the most basic expression- [i]assignment[/i], which is accomplished with the assignment operator =. [code=Java] int x = 5; // declare x and // initialize it to 5 int y = x; // assign value of x to y // calculate run-time long duration = System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime;[/code]
int x = 5; // declare x and // initialize it to 5 int y = x; // assign value of x to y
It's very important to distinguish a single =, which denotes assignment, from the double ==, which tests for equality. Many hours of frustration have been wasted by programmers mistyping these operators. [b][SIZE=14pt]Arithmetic Operators[/size][/b] Java provides the following arithmetic operators. [ul][*]addition: + [*]subtraction: - [*]multiplication: * [*]division: /[/ul] They can be applied to any of the integer or floating point types. [code=Java] int a = 1 + 1; // 2 int b = a - 1; // 1 int c = a * 2; // 4 int d = c / 2; // 2[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]The Increment Operator: ++[/size][/b] The increment operator ++ increments the value of its operand, and returns the result. The operator may appear before or after the variable. It if appears [i]before[/i] the variable, it is known as a pre-increment, and the increment happens [i]before[/i] the assignment. [code=Java] int foo = 0; int bar = ++foo; System.out.println("foo is: " + foo); System.out.println("bar is: " + bar); [/code] This would result in:
foo is: 1 bar is: 1
[b][SIZE=14pt]The Increment Operator: ++[/size][/b] If it appears [i]after[/i] the variable, it is known as a post-increment, and the increment happens [i]after[/i] the assignment. [code=Java] int foo = 0; int bar = foo++; System.out.println("foo is: " + foo); System.out.println("bar is: " + bar);[/code] This would result in:
foo is: 1 bar is: 0
[b][SIZE=14pt]The Decrement Operator: --[/size][/b] The decrement operator -- has a pre and post form, and behaves similarly. [code=Java] int foo = 1; int bar = --foo; System.out.println("foo is: " + foo); System.out.println("bar is: " + bar);[/code] This would result in:
foo is: 0 bar is: 0
[code=Java] int foo = 1; int bar = foo--; System.out.println("foo is: " + foo); System.out.println("bar is: " + bar);[/code] This would result in:
foo is: 0 bar is: 1
[b][SIZE=14pt]Equality and Relational Operators[/size][/b] The equality and relational operators are used for comparing two values.
== equal to != not equal to > greater than >= greater than or equal to < less than <= less than or equal to
[code=Java] x == y // is x equal to y? x != y // is x NOT equal to y? x > y // is x greater than y? x >= y // is x greater than OR equal to y? x < y // is x less than y? x <= y // is x less than OR equal to y?[/code] [b][SIZE=14pt]Conditional (Boolean) Operators[/size][/b] The conditional operators are used for forming logical expressions, much in the same way "and", "or" and "not" are used in English. In Java, the operator && (double ampersand) returns true only if [i]both[/i] of its operands evaluate to true. This works like "and" in English. [code=Java] boolean hasTail = true; boolean fourLegs = true; boolean isDog = hasTail && fourLegs; // true[/code] [code=Java] boolean hasTail = true; boolean fourLegs = false; boolean isDog = hasTail && fourLegs; // false[/code] The operator || (double pipe) returns true only if [i]either[/i] or [i]both[/i] of its operands evaluate to true. This works like "or" in English. [code=Java] boolean isCat = true; boolean isDog = true; boolean hasTail = isCat || isDog; // true[/code] [code=Java] boolean isCat = true; boolean isDog = false; boolean hasTail = isCat || isDog; // true[/code] [code=Java] boolean isCat = false; boolean isDog = true; boolean hasTail = isCat || isDog; // true[/code] [code=Java] boolean isCat = false; boolean isDog = false; boolean hasTail = isCat || isDog; // false[/code] The operator ! (exclamation point) returns the [i]reverse[/i] its operand. [code=Java] boolean isCat = false; boolean isDog = ! isCat; // true[/code] [code=Java] boolean isCat = true; boolean isDog = ! isCat; // false[/code]

item.title: Intro to Java
item.dc:creator: @neroxx neroxx
item.description:
@neroxx wrote:

What I did to compile and run HelloWorld:
I made the HelloWorld.java file on my desktop, then I opened notebook and wrote: @echo off title compiler "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_30\bin\javac.exe" -cp . *.java pause (Just change the jdk version to your) That compiler worked fine for me, but remember to save it on your desktop! To run it I wrote this in notepad: @ECHO OFF JAVA HelloWorld pause Then I got it to run But remember to save it as .bat files

Hope this maybe help xD

Read full topic

item.title: Intro to Java
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

The Wanderer:

Go to my computer. Click on c drive. look for your jdk. should be in either Program Files\Java or Program Files(x86)\Java. Next after you click on that click on bin. Then go into the navigation bar and type \javac. Then copy that whole entire thing and in your batch script put “your directory to javac goes here” in place of javac. make sure to keep the quotations.

still dont get it… can u plz tv me

Read full topic

@the_wanderer wrote:

Go to my computer. Click on c drive. look for your jdk. should be in either Program Files\Java or Program Files(x86)\Java. Next after you click on that click on bin. Then go into the navigation bar and type \javac. Then copy that whole entire thing and in your batch script put “your directory to javac goes here” in place of javac. make sure to keep the quotations.

item.title: Intro to Java
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

You need to either

  1. Go into your program files and locate your JDK (if you don’t have it installed) and use the directory as the javac, e.g., “C:\Windows\ProgramFiles\Java\jdk1.6\bin\javac.exe”
  2. Fix your environment variables.

Read full topic

item.title: Intro to Java
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:62, topic:422992”][quote author=lemme_winks_ link=topic=525655.msg3903254#msg3903254 date=1327964199]

Or you couls create a getter and setter.

[code=Java]boolean canRoll;

public boolean canRoll() {
return canRoll;
}

public boolean setCanRoll(boolean canRoll) {
this.canRoll = canRoll;
}[/code]

Then you could do something like…

if(canRoll()) { // do stuff }

holy shit completely unnecessary…

public boolean canRoll;

…

its good for people who just want that boolean to be called from that class and nowhere else…

This is covered in the basics of Java.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/

…what?

he was encapsulating a boolean given full functionality–booleans do not have that much functionality. it’s 0,1, -1,0, -1,1 etc. you can modify public members of a class from anywhere.
[/quote]
The boolean wasn’t public, and only has two functionailties… true/false.[/quote]

that was the reason why i posted…

Read full topic

Or you couls create a getter and setter.

[code=Java]boolean canRoll;

public boolean canRoll() {
return canRoll;
}

public boolean setCanRoll(boolean canRoll) {
this.canRoll = canRoll;
}[/code]

Then you could do something like…

if(canRoll()) { // do stuff }

holy shit completely unnecessary…

public boolean canRoll;

…

its good for people who just want that boolean to be called from that class and nowhere else…

This is covered in the basics of Java.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/
[/quote]

…what?

he was encapsulating a boolean given full functionality–booleans do not have that much functionality. it’s 0,1, -1,0, -1,1 etc. you can modify public members of a class from anywhere.[/quote]
The boolean wasn’t public, and only has two functionailties… true/false.

item.title: Intro to Java
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Or you couls create a getter and setter.

[code=Java]boolean canRoll;

public boolean canRoll() {
return canRoll;
}

public boolean setCanRoll(boolean canRoll) {
this.canRoll = canRoll;
}[/code]

Then you could do something like…

if(canRoll()) { // do stuff }
